stem: The patient is exhibiting signs and symptoms related to heart failure. Based on the assessment data in the EHR, indicate whether each finding supports right-sided heart failure, left-sided heart failure, or both.

itemContext.sbar: S: Robert Jameson, 72-year-old male, admitted 2 days ago for acute MI. He developed new onset dyspnea and lower extremity edema this morning. O2 sat 88% on room air. B: History of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Acute MI confirmed by troponin levels and EKG changes. A: At 0700, patient reported increased shortness of breath. Auscultation reveals crackles bilaterally in lower lobes. Lower extremity edema is 2+ bilaterally. IV of 0.9% NS at 20 mL/hr. Medications include metoprolol, lisinopril, aspirin, and furosemide. At 0730, furosemide 40mg IV push was administered. R: I recommend further evaluation for possible heart failure exacerbation and potential adjustments to medication regimen. I will continue to monitor vital signs, oxygen saturation, and respiratory status. Notified Dr. Smith at 0735.

rationale.correct: Elevated BNP and crackles bilaterally indicate fluid overload, a hallmark of heart failure. Crackles are more indicative of left-sided heart failure due to pulmonary congestion. Peripheral edema is a primary sign of right-sided heart failure due to systemic venous congestion. Tachycardia is a compensatory mechanism seen in both left and right sided heart failure. Hyponatremia can occur in both due to fluid retention and dilution.
rationale.incorrect: Failing to recognize the specific signs and symptoms related to left-sided versus right-sided heart failure will lead to incorrect categorization. Understanding the pathophysiology behind each symptom is crucial. For example, edema is caused by increased hydrostatic pressure in the venous system in right-sided heart failure, while crackles are caused by fluid backing up into the lungs in left-sided heart failure.
clinicalPearls: BNP is a key diagnostic marker for heart failure.
Crackles indicate fluid in the alveoli and are a sign of pulmonary edema.
Peripheral edema is a sign of systemic venous congestion.

questionTrap.trap: The question trap is to assume that all signs and symptoms of heart failure are indicative of both left and right-sided heart failure. Students may also incorrectly attribute all respiratory symptoms to left-sided heart failure.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the specific mechanisms causing each symptom. Remember that left-sided heart failure primarily affects the lungs, while right-sided heart failure primarily affects the systemic circulation.

mnemonic.title: FORWARD and BACKWARD
mnemonic.expansion: FORWARD: Right-sided failure symptoms are systemic (e.g., edema). BACKWARD: Left-sided failure symptoms are pulmonary (e.g., crackles).
